title: Torque - angle of force on wrench

content.question: An engineer tightens a bolt with a wrench. The engineer exerts a force of magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> near the middle of the wrench at an angle <math alttext="phi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ϕ</mi></math> to the normal, as shown. A student claims that to increase the torque exerted on the bolt by the wrench, the engineer could decrease the angle <math alttext="phi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ϕ</mi></math> between the force and the normal. Is the student’s claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because decreasing the angle will increase the distance between the axis of rotation and the application of the force.
Yes, because decreasing the angle with the normal will increase the angle between the force and the position vector.
No, because the torque is proportional to the sine of the angle, which will decrease with decreasing angle.
No, because the magnitude of the force and the distance between the application of the force and the axis of rotation will not change.

content.answer: Yes, because decreasing the angle with the normal will increase the angle between the force and the position vector.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
